short-title.#text:
Investing in Innovation for
			 Education Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is amended by adding at the end the
			 following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of
			 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/t:IV
usc/20/7101/etseq

text.#text: The purposes of this part are to—

fund the
				identification, development, evaluation, and expansion of innovative,
				evidence-based practices, programs, and strategies in order to
				significantly—

increase student
				academic achievement and decrease achievement gaps;

increase high
				school graduation rates;

increase college
				enrollment rates and rates of college persistence;

improve teacher
				and school leader effectiveness; and

increase the
				identification of innovative educational strategies in rural areas; and

support the rapid
				development, expansion, and adoption of tools and resources that improve the
				efficiency, effectiveness, or pace of adoption of such educational practices,
				programs, and strategies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may
				reserve not more than 10 percent of the funds appropriated under

for each fiscal year to carry out activities of national significance, which
				activities may include—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4408

text.#text: The
capacity building;

technical assistance, including to
				applicants from rural areas;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4404

the recruitment of peer-reviewers,

carrying out prize awards consistent with

				out advanced research and development activities, including research and
				activities in rural areas.

Program
				authorized; length of grants; priorities

				educational agencies, educational service agencies, and nonprofit organizations
				that propose to provide support to 1 or more public schools or local
				educational agencies, or both, consistent with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4405

shall award grants under this part for a
				period of not more than 3 years, and may extend such grants for an additional
				2-year period if the grantee demonstrates to the

that it is making
				significant progress on the program performance measures identified in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4406

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall ensure that not less than 25 percent of
				the funds awarded under

for any fiscal year are for projects
				that meet both of the following requirements:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4403/ss:a

text.#text: The

The grantee
				is—

a local
				educational agency with an urban-centric district locale code of 32, 33, 41,
				42, or 43, as determined by the

a consortium of
				such local educational agencies; or

an educational
				service agency or a nonprofit organization with demonstrated expertise in
				serving students from rural areas.

A majority of the
				schools to be served by the project are designated with a school locale code of
				41, 42, or 43, or a combination of such codes, as determined by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
may give priority to an eligible
				entity that includes, in its application under
, a plan to—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4404

text.#text:
In
				awarding grants under this part, the

improve early
				learning outcomes;

support college
				access and success;

support family
				and community engagement;

support the
				effective use of education technology to improve teaching and learning;

serve schools in
				rural local educational agencies.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall set standards for the quality of
				evidence that an applicant shall provide in order to demonstrate that the
				activities the applicant proposes to carry out with funds under this part are
				likely to succeed in improving student outcomes or outcomes on other
				performance measures. These standards may include any of the following:

text.#text: The

Strong evidence
				that the activities proposed by the applicant will have a statistically
				significant effect on student academic achievement, student growth, or outcomes
				on other performance measures.

Moderate evidence
				that the activities proposed by the applicant will improve student academic
				achievement, student growth, or outcomes on other performance measures.

A rationale based
				on research findings or a reasonable hypothesis that the activities proposed by
				the applicant will improve student academic achievement, student growth, or
				outcomes on other performance measures.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
at such time, in such manner,
				and containing such information as the
may reasonably require.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4403/ss:e

text.#text: The

Each local educational agency, educational service agency,
				or nonprofit organization that receives a grant under this part—

shall use the
				grant funds to address, at a minimum, 1 of the following areas of school
				innovations:

Improving the
				effectiveness of teachers and school leaders and promoting equity in the
				distribution of effective teachers and school leaders.

Strengthening the
				use of data to improve teaching and learning.

Providing
				high-quality instruction based on rigorous standards that build toward college
				and career readiness and measuring students' mastery using high-quality
				assessments aligned to those standards.

Turning around
				the lowest-performing schools.

Any other area of
				school innovation, as determined by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4406

text.#text:
shall use those
				funds to develop or expand strategies to improve the performance of high-need
				students on the performance measures described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, of the
				innovative practices carried out with the grant.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:4404/ss:b/p:9

text.#text:
may use the grant
				funds for an independent evaluation, as required by

A nonprofit organization that receives a grant under
				this part may use the grant funds to make subgrants to other entities to
				provide support to 1 or more schools or local educational agencies. Any such
				entity shall comply with the requirements of this part relating to grantees, as
				appropriate.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall

				under this part. These measures, at a minimum, shall track the grantee's
